L2_gloss: official, officer (of the Indian government of the

big, fat, wide
pramod ʈʰi innen huʈʰu.Pramod is a fat foreigner/Indian.
Antonyms: boi͂ja (“small”), telo (“thin”)

An evidential suffix, marking an action or situation that is immediately verifiable by the listener(s).
Allema, innen ɖag ɖ-eŋge-jə.Come, the foreigners have brought the coconuts [as you can see right now].
Antonym: -ʈʰe (non-verifiable evidential suffix)

mother
tenmej kajaTenmey's mother
ma-kaja ʈʰi innen.My mother is a non-Jarawa (a foreigner).
this, these, li aːw ʈʰi talu.This bow is long., Synonym:
this, these, this one, these ones, li topo t-ita-b.He
me; us (singular and plural first-person pronoun in
I; we (both singular and plural first-person pronoun,

not (negating adverb)
mi allema-hə naɖem.I might not come.
unnə naɖem.Don't go home.
Synonym: -ma

tree
tenmej taːŋ ɖi ičilo-wa.Tenmey is cutting the tree.
Pandanus andamanensis, a pandanus palm indigenous to the Andamans; the Jarawa use it for medicine and wooden baskets
the fronds or leaves of Nypa fruticans, the nipa palm; the Jarawa use these as adornment

short
mi innen wɛ ʈʰi učəhə.We are shorter than foreigners (non-Jarawas, Indians).
Synonyms: orgontʰo, boi͂ja
Antonym: orkalaŋ (“tall”)
Post-back vowel allomorphic form of -jə (an evidential suffix marking verifiable action).

make; adds a causative sense.
mi əŋka:b ɖi woǰoʈʰo iŋ-tapo ɖi inčo-wa.I make/made the old man drink the fresh water.
Synonym: wa- (causative prefix for certain verbs)

the; marks the preceding noun phrase as definite, whose identity is already known by direct observation or by context.
mi napo ɖ-əjojəba.I see/saw the fish.
oloŋa ɖi ahapela.The piglet is/was running.

The Jarawa copula, largely equivalent to English "to be".
Connects a preceding or implied noun phrase, and a subsequent complement, either another noun phrase or an adjective. Not used for personal pronouns.
ʈʰi buʈʰə.It is close by.
babu ʈʰi innen.The officer is a foreigner/an Indian.
Marks that the following verb has an adverbial usage.
li ʈʰi čawaja bəᵼʈʰe.He went while walking.
Optionally intervenes between an adjective used as subject, and a subsequent verb.
malawə ʈʰi allema.Many [people] have come.
